body:
Data dashboards display metrics on traffic and performance. They help you to make good decisions about your product. 


Let's look at:

  • What a data informed mentality is 
  • What strong metrics are
  • Which metrics could be appropriate to your stage
title: Intro

body:
If you have done other DBA courses, you'll be familiar with the Lean approach to developing products. 

That involves:

  • making a guess (hypothesis)
  • doing some work to test it (experiment)
  • measuring the results (analytics).


A data informed business should be gathering data that helps them to ask the right questions and decide on a good course of action. 


Finding the right things to measure takes time, thinking and iteration. 


The figures need to be interpreted in context with your experiences and intuitions too. Doing this right is part art and part science. 


Having too much data and failing to take account of context can be distracting and misleading, so a nuanced approach is recommended. 


This is called being data informed (rather than data driven).
displayTitle: What does it mean to be data informed?
title: What does it mean to be data informed?

body:
Each business will choose how many metrics to focus on. 


In the early days, just having one metric could help you to stay focused. 


Here are four criteria to help you pick a suitable metric that will really help you to make good decisions (rather than just feel good about yourself).

_items.title: Tied to the product
_items.body:
This means that when this number changes, something has changed about your business.


This must represent both good and bad change.

_items.title: Being measured as a rate or ratio
_items.body:
In younger companies, the overall size of the number doesn’t matter.


Is having 10 customers good or great? You just don’t know yet. But measuring how quickly your customer base is growing, that is important. 


Being able to say that 'our customer base is up 30% from last week' is much more insightful.

_items.title: Comparable
_items.body: A good KPI should be comparable to other activities in your business and to your competitors.

_items.title: Explainable
_items.body:
If you can’t explain what a KPI represents to someone else involved in your business (employee, partner, investor) then it’s too complicated. 


Stick to simple numbers.

title: Attributes of a good KPI

body: Devin Hunt walks us through examples of strong metrics to measure performance in a startup.
title: How to write better KPI

_media._source: C9M2 : Key performance indicators (KPI) from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: This section includes some popular key performance indicators (KPI) you might consider using.

_items.body: Monthly active users: the number of people using your app/product website every month
_items.title: MAU

_items.body: Daily active users: the number of people using your app/product website every month.
_items.title: DAU

_items.body:
Average revenue per user: how much money you make per user on your site.


For example, 100 users who bring in 1000 dollars. 


The ARPU is $10.
_items.title: ARPU

_items.body:
Customer lifetime value.


For example, for a café owner, the CLV is the total amount of money they make from customers, from their first visit to their last.
_items.title: CLV

_items.body: This is the average score you get from customers answering to the question 'how likely would you be to recommend our product or service'?
_items.title: Net promoter score

title: Examples of good KPI

body: Michelle Yu, founder of Songkick, shares how they picked their first KPI, the mistakes they made and how they tweaked their KPI over time.
title: Founders' stories: KPI at Songkick

_media._source: C9M2 : Interview+with+Michelle+You from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

title: T9C1Q1 Your approach to metrics

body: According to Lean analytics, what should companies be measuring while they are still searching for a solid business model?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


As a new business finds its' place in the market, it should choose metrics that focus on stickiness and empathy. These will keep the business focused on finding a business model that works.


Once the business is established in the market, it should choose metrics that focus on scale and vitality which will help it to grow.

As a new business finds its' place in the market, it should choose metrics that focus on stickiness and empathy. These will keep the business focused on finding a business model that works.


Once the business is established in the market, it should choose metrics that focus on scale and vitality which will help it to grow.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


As a new business finds its place in the market, it should choose metrics that focus on stickiness and empathy. These will keep the business focused on finding a business model that works. 


Once the business is established in the market, it should choose metrics that focus on scale and vitality which will help it to grow.

title: T9C1Q3 What makes good metrics?

body:
Dashboards help you to make good decisions about your product. 


Don't forget that data isn't everything and that finding the right things to measure is an ongoing project.
title: What should I measure? Let's wrap it up

body:
Cohorts is a technique used to group customers by some similar attribute. 


Let's have a look at:

  • What a cohort analysis is
  • How you set up a cohort analysis 
  • How to analyse a cohort dashboard
title: Make sense of data through cohorts

_source: C9M3 : Introduction to cohorts from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

This is a long one, but worthwhile, so take your time with each part and follow along with the examples discussed.
title: What are cohorts?

title: T9C2Q1 What is a cohort?

body:
Consider this scenario.


You are developing a mobile app for shopping. Every 5 - 6 weeks you publish a new version of the app. 


Which one of the following is the best way to group cohorts to monitor the effect the app updates are having?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


In this case, the best way to group users into cohorts is by looking at the version of the app they were using.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


In this case, the best way to group users into cohorts is by looking at the version of the app they were using.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


In this case, the best way to group users into cohorts is by looking at the version of the app they were using.

_items.text: Week customer joined
Week customer bought first item
Number of items bought
App version when customer joined

title: T9C2Q2 How to group cohorts

body:
Cohort analysis is one of the most powerful and simple techniques for analysing performance. 


Segmentation of your customers into cohorts and measuring how they change behaviour provides you with information to make decisions.


Cohort analysis can be used to monitor marketing, new product features, how well sales are converting - just about anything, really!
title: Make sense of data through cohorts. Let's wrap it up

body:
Startup businesses use funnels to 'stage' their customers' journey through cohorts.


Let's look at:

  • What funnels might look like for a startup
  • How to combine funnels with cohorts
title: Funnels

body: Here is a summary of the steps in a typical funnel.

_items.body:
Acquisition measures how many people enter the funnel. 


An acquisition event should be tied to a potential customer understanding of what you’re offering as a company. 


For a job site like Escape the City, this is someone arriving on their homepage. Everyone who hits their front page is a potential customer.


For coffee roasters Pact Coffee, it’s when a customer orders their first bag of coffee.
_items.title: Acquisition

_items.body: The activation step should measure when a customer is using your business / service as it’s intended.
_items.title: Activation
Retention
_items.body:
Retention is the most important metric for a startup. 


This goal must correspond to a user becoming a meaningful customer.

_items.title: Referral
_items.body:
When a customer actively brings in new customers.


 Not all companies have that step.

_items.title: Revenue
_items.body:
Easy! 


Are you making money from a customer now? 


Often money can be made early in the customer journey, so this should tie to repeatable or significant revenue.

title: Steps of the funnel

body: We’ll break down how different businesses use funnels and how they chose different funnel stages.
displayTitle: Founder stories: Pact Coffee and funnels
title: Founder stories: Pact Coffee and funnels

title: T9C3Q3 Stages of the startup funnel

body:
The startup funnel is a series of milestones in a customer's journey. 


Businesses need to tie these to unique customer actions in their own business context. 


By combining cohorts and funnels, businesses can get a detailed breakdown of where customers might be dropping off and the impact that different interventions might have on customers' behaviour.
title: Convert customers using the funnel. Let's wrap it up

body:
There are a range of formats for gathering data, including analytics, surveys, Net Promoter Scores, and rich case studies.


There are a multitude of ways to share the data with colleagues in a clear and meaningful way.


Let's look at:

  • How analytics works and what it is useful for 
  • What Net Promoter Scores is and how it is calculated 
  • When and how surveys can be useful 
  • How to share data with clients through case studies
  • How to share data with colleagues through dashboards
title: Capture data for analytics

body:
Analytics is data about how and where customers are moving around on your website. 


This software suite (there are several you can choose from) can tell you which sources customers came from, for example Facebook, Adwords, SEO.


It can also be set up to track particular events, such as every time customers sign up to an email or make a sale. 


Using some form of analytics is a must to understand how your customers are currently interacting with you and how you can do better.
title: What is analytics?

body:
Here is an overview of some popular analytics tools.


Some are free, but some cost.

_items.title: Google analytics
_items.body:
The gold standard. 


This widely used analytics package is available online and can be used with almost any website creator. 


It allows you to track page views and traffic sources, right out of the box. If you are using any type of online ads for marketing, this is a must.

_items.title: Kissmetrics and Mixpanel
_items.body:
These analytics packages offer similar features to Google analytics, but both shine in one key area: funnels. 


Both of these services were built to help understand and optimise your sales and boarding funnels. They are also very mature and work well with many other services.

_items.title: GoSquared
_items.body: Originally launched as the first real time analytics service, GoSquared has grown into a robust online analytics package which can perform all the functions of the above competitors.

_items.title: TruRating
_items.body:
If you have retail locations, TruRating allows you to collect customer analytics directly from the point of sale.


This allows physical stores to be as responsive as online outlets.

title: Useful analytics tools

_source: C9M5 : Net Promoter Score from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
body: Devin Hunt introduces us to the Net Promoter Score, an important way to measure the performance of your business.
displayTitle: What is a Net Promoter Score (NPS)?
title: What is a Net Promoter Score (NPS)?

body:
the Net Promoter Score (NPS) is a number between minus 100 and 100 that represents the proportion of customers who are advocates.


So how does it work?

_items.body:
Customers are asked the question:


How likely is it that you would recommend our company/product/service to a friend or colleague?


They express their answer as a number between 0 (no likelihood) and 10 (absolutely!)

People who answer 9 to 10 are promoters - the engaged portion of your customer base who will promote your products organically and bring in more business.


Those who rate between 0 to 6 are detractors and are considered unhappy customers.


Those who rate between 7 to 8 are considered passive and have no positive or negative effect on your company’s future.

To calculate your business’s NPS, subtract the percentage of detractors from the percentage of promoters.


NPS = % promoters - % detractors


In other words:


NPS = (number of promoters - number of detractors) / (total people asked)


NPS can range from minus 100 to 100. 


Anything over 50 is considered excellent. Anything below 0 needs work.

title: Using the Net Promoter Score

body:
Good dashboards make KPI and other business critical data accessible and understandable to the whole team.


A good dashboard should highlight your KPI clearly. For great examples of dashboards check out out posts by Christoph Janz and these examples by GeckoBoard.


Show me - A KPI dashboard for early-stage SaaS startups


Show me - GeckoBoard Blog


As your business grows it's common to have multiple dashboards for different teams. 


For example, the sales team can have a dashboard that monitors the sales pipeline and funnel while the customer service can have one which displays how many customer requests are pending.


Devin Hunt tells us more.
title: Use dashboards to share data

_media._source: C9M6 - Sharing performance- dashboards from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Here are some tools to consider for displaying and sharing your data with colleagues.

_items.body:
Yep, just a plain old spreadsheet. 


Hopefully, the exercises we provide throughout this course have demonstrated the power of a well-built spreadsheet. If you’re just starting up, start with a spreadsheet!
_items.title: Sheets

_items.body:
Geckoboard allows you to quickly build a KPI dashboard for any business purpose. 


It integrates with many online analytics systems.
_items.title: Geckoboard

_items.body: Similar to Geckoboard, Leftronic is a dashboard creation tool that uses different services and data feeds to visualise your KPI.
_items.title: Leftronic

_items.body: Freeboard offers similar features to the above but with a focus on Internet of Things devices.
_items.title: Freeboard

title: Dashboard tools

body:
Testimonials aren’t complicated. 


The hard part is gathering them. You should always be getting feedback from your customers, whether it is by interview, surveys, or even during a customer service experience. If a quote comes up that would be useful in a promotional setting, get their permission to use it.


In a more traditional business-to-business context be sure to follow up with a client after work has completed. Ask them something along the lines of : 'Could you describe how the project went?'.


The response usually will be a great testimonial. 


Unless of course, the project was a complete failure. Do not be afraid to ask them to modify their response to better fit your needs. Often you can write the quote for your client, and ask them to agree to it.
title: Why bother with testimonials?

body: Here is a suggestion on how you might structure a case study.

_items.body: A brief introduction to the whole project
_items.title: Summary
Problem
_items.body: What needed to be accomplished?

_items.title: Solution
_items.body: How the project was approached

Was it successful? How successful was it?


If not, why?
_items.title: Outcome

_items.body:
Show the evidence to support how the project was approached.


Also a great place for customer testimonials!
_items.title: Data

title: Structuring case studies

in other words:

There are a range of formats for gathering data including analytics, surveys, Net Promoter Scores, and rich case studies. 


You also now have ways to share the data with colleagues in a clear and meaningful way.
